title: Psalms Chapter 4 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 4 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 4 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 4.

questions.question: Who is the author of Psalms Chapter 4?
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:1 states this is a Psalm of David.

questions.question: In Psalms 4:1, David asks God to hear him when he _____?
questions.correctAnswer: calls
questions.explanation: David asks God to hear him when he calls, as stated in Psalms 4:1.

questions.question: According to Psalms 4:2, what do the sons of men turn David's glory into?
questions.correctAnswer: Shame
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:2 asks how long sons of men will turn his glory into shame.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 4:3 states the LORD will hear when David calls unto Him.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:3 confirms that the LORD will hear when David calls unto Him.

questions.question: What does Psalms 4:4 advise to do while communing with your own heart?
questions.correctAnswer: Be still
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:4 says to commune with your own heart upon your bed and be still.

questions.question: According to Psalms 4:5, what should one offer?
questions.correctAnswer: Sacrifices of righteousness
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:5 instructs to offer the sacrifices of righteousness and trust in the LORD.

questions.question: In Psalms 4:6, what do many people say about good?
options: Who will show us any good?
questions.correctAnswer: Who will show us any good?
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:6 states many say, 'Who will shew us any good?'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 4:7 talks about gladness in the heart being more than when corn and wine increased.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:7 says God has put gladness in the heart more than in the time their corn and wine increased.

questions.question: According to Psalms 4:8, why can the psalmist sleep in peace?
options: Because the LORD makes him dwell in safety
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD makes him dwell in safety
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:8 states the psalmist sleeps in peace because the LORD only makes him dwell in safety.

questions.question: What is the LORD called in Psalms 4:1?
questions.correctAnswer: God of my righteousness
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:1 calls God the 'God of my righteousness'.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Psalms 4:4: 'Stand in awe, and sin not: commune with your own heart upon your bed, and be _____.'
questions.correctAnswer: still
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:4 ends with 'and be still.'

questions.question: Who does the LORD set apart for Himself according to Psalms 4:3?
questions.correctAnswer: The godly
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:3 says the LORD hath set apart him that is godly for Himself.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 4:5 encourages putting trust in the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:5 advises to offer sacrifices of righteousness and put your trust in the LORD.

questions.question: According to Psalms 4:6, what does the psalmist ask the LORD to lift up upon us?
questions.correctAnswer: The light of thy countenance
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:6 requests the LORD to lift up the light of His countenance upon us.

questions.question: In Psalms 4:7, what has God put in the psalmist's heart?
questions.correctAnswer: Gladness
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:7 states that God has put gladness in the psalmist's heart.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 4 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 4 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 4:1, what biblical truth would you share about God's response to distress?
options: God enlarges and hears us in distress
God ignores the cries of the distressed
questions.correctAnswer: God enlarges and hears us in distress
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:1 teaches that God hears when we call and enlarges us in our distress, showing His mercy and attentiveness to prayer.

questions.question: How does Psalms 4:2 warn believers about pursuing vanity and falsehood?
options: It questions how long they will love vanity and seek lies
It encourages seeking after worldly pleasures
It says vanity is a sign of godliness
It promises material blessings for vanity
questions.correctAnswer: It questions how long they will love vanity and seek lies
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:2 challenges believers to consider the shame that comes from loving vanity and seeking falsehood, warning against such behavior.

questions.question: What assurance does Psalms 4:3 provide about God's relationship with the godly?
options: The LORD sets apart the godly and hears their calls
The godly must earn God's attention
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD sets apart the godly and hears their calls
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:3 confirms that God specially sets apart those who are godly and listens when they call upon Him, assuring believers of His attentive care.

questions.question: Based on Psalms 4:4, what practical discipline is encouraged to overcome sin and anxiety?
options: Stand in awe, avoid sin, reflect quietly on your bed
Ignore your heart and be busy
questions.correctAnswer: Stand in awe, avoid sin, reflect quietly on your bed
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:4 encourages believers to fear God, refrain from sin, and practice quiet self-examination and stillness as a way to maintain spiritual health.

questions.question: How does Psalms 4:5 teach believers to demonstrate their trust in the Lord through actions?
options: Offer sacrifices of righteousness and trust the LORD
Ignore righteousness and focus on wealth
questions.correctAnswer: Offer sacrifices of righteousness and trust the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:5 instructs believers to actively practice righteousness and place their trust in God, illustrating faith through both devotion and ethical conduct.

questions.question: A believer feels discouraged and asks, 'Who will show us any good?' How would Psalms 4:6 guide your encouragement?
options: Pray for the LORD to lift His countenance and show favor
Seek good from worldly sources only
questions.correctAnswer: Pray for the LORD to lift His countenance and show favor
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:6 acknowledges doubts about goodness but encourages praying for God's favorable attention to bring blessing and hope.

questions.question: What does Psalms 4:7 reveal about the source of true gladness?
options: Gladness comes from God more than material abundance
questions.correctAnswer: Gladness comes from God more than material abundance
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:7 expresses that God puts gladness in the heart surpassing joy from increased corn and wine, showing spiritual joy outweighs material blessings.

questions.question: How does Psalms 4:8 teach us about peace and security in daily life?
options: We can lie down in peace and sleep safely because God protects us
We must worry to stay safe
Peace comes from avoiding all risks
questions.correctAnswer: We can lie down in peace and sleep safely because God protects us
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:8 assures that trusting God allows believers to rest peacefully, knowing He alone provides safety and security.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 4:1, God only hears the prayers of the righteous when they call.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:1 refers to God as the 'God of my righteousness,' indicating He hears the calls of those who live righteously.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 4:4 encourages believers to be still and reflect on their hearts to avoid sin.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:4 instructs believers to stand in awe, not sin, and to commune with their own hearts in quietness, encouraging self-reflection.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 4:5 instructs believers to offer the sacrifices of _______, and put your trust in the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: righteousness
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:5 teaches offering sacrifices of righteousness, referring to acts of obedience and faithfulness, as a sign of trusting God.

questions.question: How does Psalms 4:2 challenge believers to examine their attitudes about glory and truth?
options: It asks how long they will shame God's glory and love vanity
It tells them to seek glory at any cost
It says truth is less important than popularity
It claims glory comes from human approval
questions.correctAnswer: It asks how long they will shame God's glory and love vanity
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:2 questions the persistent turning of God's glory into shame and the love of vanity and falsehood, urging self-examination and repentance.

questions.question: In light of Psalms 4:3, how should believers view their identity in relation to God?
options: They are set apart by the LORD for Himself
They are left to fend for themselves
Their identity depends on worldly status
questions.correctAnswer: They are set apart by the LORD for Himself
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:3 reveals that God has set apart the godly for Himself, affirming the believer's special identity and relationship with God.

questions.question: What practical advice does Psalms 4:4 give for overcoming temptation and sin?
options: Stand in awe of God, avoid sin, and practice quiet self-reflection
questions.correctAnswer: Stand in awe of God, avoid sin, and practice quiet self-reflection
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:4 encourages fear of the Lord, abstaining from sin, and quiet communion with one's heart as means to resist temptation.

questions.question: According to Psalms 4:7, what surpasses the joy of abundant harvest and wine?
options: The gladness God puts in the heart
questions.correctAnswer: The gladness God puts in the heart
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:7 states that God gives a joy in the heart that exceeds joy from material abundance, emphasizing spiritual over material blessings.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 4 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 4.

questions.question: In Psalms 4:1, David calls God the 'God of my righteousness.' How does this title correlate with the New Testament concept of justification by faith?
options: It emphasizes God's role as a personal righteous judge, similar to Romans 3:22
It refers to God's physical strength as described in Exodus 15:6
It aligns with the concept of God as a warrior in Revelation 19:11
It highlights God's mercy without reference to righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes God's role as a personal righteous judge, similar to Romans 3:22
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:1 speaks of God as the source of righteousness, paralleling Romans 3:22 where righteousness is through faith in Jesus Christ, emphasizing God as a righteous judge who justifies.

questions.question: Psalms 4:2 uses the phrase 'love vanity, and seek after leasing.' What Hebrew literary device is primarily employed here?
options: Parallelism, highlighting the futility of false pursuits
Metaphor, comparing vanity to a fleeting shadow
Alliteration, emphasizing the sound 'l' in leasing and love
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism, highlighting the futility of false pursuits
questions.explanation: The verse uses synonymous parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic device, to emphasize the emptiness of pursuing vanity and falsehood.

questions.question: Which Old Testament figure is typologically foreshadowed by the phrase in Psalms 4:3, 'the LORD hath set apart him that is godly for himself'?
options: Melchizedek, as a priest set apart without genealogy (Hebrews 7)
Moses, chosen to lead Israel out of Egypt
David, as the anointed king of Israel
Elijah, the prophet set apart to confront Baal worship
questions.correctAnswer: Melchizedek, as a priest set apart without genealogy (Hebrews 7)
questions.explanation: The setting apart of the godly in Psalms 4:3 typologically resonates with Melchizedek’s unique priesthood described in Hebrews 7, symbolizing a divine appointment.

questions.question: How does the command in Psalms 4:4 to 'Stand in awe, and sin not' reflect ancient Near Eastern cultural values regarding divine reverence?
options: It stresses the importance of fear of God to maintain social order and covenant fidelity
It encourages fear to prevent rebellion against earthly kings
It promotes ritual purity before sacrifices only
It reflects a psychological state rather than ethical conduct
questions.correctAnswer: It stresses the importance of fear of God to maintain social order and covenant fidelity
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, reverence ('awe') of the deity was essential for upholding social and covenantal norms, as seen in Psalms 4:4 where fear of God prevents sin.

questions.question: In Psalms 4:5, the phrase 'Offer the sacrifices of righteousness' most likely refers to which aspect of Israelite worship?
options: Ethical living as a form of spiritual sacrifice, not just ritual offerings
Animal sacrifices exclusively at the tabernacle
Burnt offerings to atone for sin only
Monetary offerings given to the priests
questions.correctAnswer: Ethical living as a form of spiritual sacrifice, not just ritual offerings
questions.explanation: The phrase suggests a broader meaning beyond ritual sacrifices, emphasizing righteous behavior as a form of offering, consistent with prophetic literature (e.g., Hosea 6:6).

questions.question: Psalms 4:6 mentions 'the light of thy countenance.' How is this expression related to the concept of divine favor in biblical theology?
options: It symbolizes God's approval and presence, akin to the Shekinah glory
It refers to literal sunlight as a blessing
It denotes the angelic host appearing with light
It is a poetic metaphor for Israel's kingship
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes God's approval and presence, akin to the Shekinah glory
questions.explanation: The 'light of thy countenance' represents God's gracious presence and favor, a motif connected to divine glory (Shekinah) in the Old Testament.

questions.question: The gladness mentioned in Psalms 4:7 is compared to the joy experienced 'in the time that their corn and their wine increased.' What agricultural significance does this hold in the ancient Israelite context?
options: It symbolizes abundance and God's blessing on the harvest and fertility
It refers to specific festival rituals involving grain and wine
It indicates reliance on trade and commerce
It is a metaphor for military victory
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes abundance and God's blessing on the harvest and fertility
questions.explanation: Corn and wine were staples representing prosperity and divine blessing; the verse contrasts spiritual joy with material abundance.

questions.question: Psalms 4:8 expresses a theme of peace and safety. Which New Testament passage echoes this assurance of divine protection during rest?
options: Matthew 11:28-30, where Jesus offers rest to the weary
Revelation 21:4, about the new heaven and earth
questions.correctAnswer: Matthew 11:28-30, where Jesus offers rest to the weary
questions.explanation: The Psalm’s assurance of peaceful sleep under God's protection parallels Jesus’ invitation to find rest in Him (Matthew 11:28-30).

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 4:4's instruction to 'commune with your own heart upon your bed, and be still' reflects a typical ancient Near Eastern practice of private reflection before sleep.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The verse encourages personal introspection and calmness before rest, a practice echoed in wisdom literature and consistent with ancient Near Eastern customs.

questions.question: In Psalms 4:1, the term 'distress' translates the Hebrew word 'tsarah.' How is this term used elsewhere in the Old Testament to convey a deeper theological meaning?
options: 'Tsarah' often indicates not only physical trouble but also spiritual testing, as seen in Daniel 3:19
'Tsarah' exclusively means famine in prophetic texts
'Tsarah' is used only for political exile in the Psalms
'Tsarah' refers to ritual impurity in Leviticus
questions.correctAnswer: 'Tsarah' often indicates not only physical trouble but also spiritual testing, as seen in Daniel 3:19
questions.explanation: The word 'tsarah' encompasses distress that tests faith, illustrated in Daniel 3:19's fiery trial, paralleling David's plea in Psalms 4:1.

questions.question: How does the phrase 'sons of men' in Psalms 4:2 function as a rhetorical device within the Psalm's structure?
options: It serves as an address to humanity emphasizing universal moral failure
It is a direct reference to the Levites only
It denotes angelic beings in this context
It highlights foreign nations surrounding Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It serves as an address to humanity emphasizing universal moral failure
questions.explanation: The phrase 'sons of men' addresses all human beings, underscoring the universal tendency toward vanity and falsehood, reinforcing the Psalm's call to righteousness.

questions.question: Which literary device is prominently used in the refrain 'Selah' in Psalms 4:2 and 4:4, and what is its probable function?
options: A musical or liturgical pause inviting reflection
A marker for the end of the Psalm
questions.correctAnswer: A musical or liturgical pause inviting reflection
questions.explanation: 'Selah' likely instructs the reader or singer to pause and reflect on the preceding message, enhancing the Psalm’s meditative quality.

questions.question: In the context of Psalms 4:5, how does the exhortation to 'put your trust in the LORD' relate to the broader Deuteronomic theme found in Deuteronomy 6:5?
options: Both emphasize wholehearted reliance on God as central to covenant faithfulness
Psalms 4:5 contradicts Deuteronomy by focusing on ritual over trust
Deuteronomy 6:5 promotes trust in leaders rather than God
The Psalm refers to trust in God only during sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: Both emphasize wholehearted reliance on God as central to covenant faithfulness
questions.explanation: Psalms 4:5 and Deuteronomy 6:5 both stress trust and love directed solely to God as foundational to Israel's relationship with Him.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'only makest me dwell in safety' in Psalms 4:8 in light of ancient Israelite societal instability?
options: It underscores God as the ultimate protector amid political and military threats
It indicates a promise of physical fortresses built by kings
It refers to the safety of the temple precincts exclusively
It is a metaphor for financial security
questions.correctAnswer: It underscores God as the ultimate protector amid political and military threats
questions.explanation: The Psalmist’s trust in God as the sole source of safety reflects Israel’s precarious situation among hostile nations and internal strife.

questions.question: True or False: The phrase 'Have mercy upon me, and hear my prayer' in Psalms 4:1 is an example of a Hebrew parallelism known as synonymous parallelism.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The two clauses express similar petitions with different wording, characteristic of synonymous parallelism common in Hebrew poetry.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 4 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 4 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 4:1, what does David ask God to do when he calls?
questions.correctAnswer: Hear him and have mercy
questions.explanation: David asks God to hear him and have mercy when he calls, showing God's responsiveness to the godly in distress (Psalms 4:1). This reflects God's attribute of mercy and attentiveness (Exodus 34:6, Psalm 86:15, Isaiah 55:6, Hebrews 4:16, 1 Peter 3:12).

questions.question: In Psalms 4:2, what behavior does David criticize among 'sons of men'?
questions.correctAnswer: Turning his glory into shame
questions.explanation: David condemns turning God's glory into shame, loving vanity, and seeking after falsehood, highlighting human sinfulness and rebellion (Psalms 4:2). This aligns with biblical teachings on human depravity and idolatry (Romans 1:21-23, Isaiah 42:8, Jeremiah 2:11, Ezekiel 36:22, 1 Corinthians 10:20).

questions.question: What assurance does David give in Psalms 4:3 about those who are godly?
options: The LORD has set them apart and will hear their calls
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD has set them apart and will hear their calls
questions.explanation: David affirms that God sets apart the godly and hears their prayers, emphasizing God's covenantal election and faithfulness (Psalms 4:3). This is consistent with scriptures on God's care for the righteous (Isaiah 41:10, Psalm 34:15, Jeremiah 29:12, John 10:27, Romans 8:28).

questions.question: What does Psalms 4:4 instruct believers to do in response to sin?
options: Stand in awe and sin not
questions.correctAnswer: Stand in awe and sin not
questions.explanation: The verse calls for reverence ('stand in awe') and abstaining from sin, showing a call to holy living and self-examination (Psalms 4:4). This aligns with biblical exhortations to fear God and pursue holiness (Ecclesiastes 12:13, 1 Peter 1:16, Hebrews 12:28, Romans 6:12, 2 Corinthians 13:5).

questions.question: According to Psalms 4:5, what should believers offer and in whom should they trust?
options: Sacrifices of righteousness and trust in the LORD
Gold and silver and trust in kings
Empty words and trust in fate
Works of the law and trust in self
questions.correctAnswer: Sacrifices of righteousness and trust in the LORD
questions.explanation: David exhorts offering righteous sacrifices and placing trust in God, highlighting faith and obedience as central to worship (Psalms 4:5). This reflects the biblical principle of faith accompanied by righteous deeds (Hebrews 11:6, Proverbs 3:5, Micah 6:8, Romans 12:1, Psalm 51:17).

questions.question: In Psalms 4:6, what is the plea made to the LORD concerning His countenance?
options: LORD, lift up the light of Your countenance upon us
LORD, hide Your face from us
LORD, send fire upon the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: LORD, lift up the light of Your countenance upon us
questions.explanation: The psalmist asks for God's favorable presence ('light of Your countenance') to shine upon His people, indicating divine blessing and acceptance (Psalms 4:6). This is a biblical image of God's grace and favor (Numbers 6:25, Psalm 31:16, 2 Corinthians 4:6, Isaiah 60:1, Luke 1:78).

questions.question: What does Psalms 4:7 say God has placed in the psalmist's heart?
options: Gladness, more than when their corn and wine increased
questions.correctAnswer: Gladness, more than when their corn and wine increased
questions.explanation: David acknowledges that God has given him joy exceeding material abundance, teaching that true gladness comes from God (Psalms 4:7). This aligns with biblical themes of joy in the Lord surpassing earthly blessings (Nehemiah 8:10, John 15:11, Philippians 4:4, Psalm 16:11, Romans 14:17).

questions.question: According to Psalms 4:8, why does the psalmist lay down and sleep in peace?
options: Because the LORD makes him dwell safely
Because he is strong and healthy
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD makes him dwell safely
questions.explanation: The psalmist rests peacefully due to God's protection, illustrating divine providence and security (Psalms 4:8). This reflects the biblical truth that God guards His people (Psalm 121:3-4, Proverbs 3:24, Isaiah 26:3, Matthew 11:28-30, Psalm 91:1-2).

questions.question: What is the significance of the term 'God of my righteousness' in Psalms 4:1?
options: It affirms God as the source of the psalmist's righteousness
It suggests the psalmist is righteous by his own works
It implies God is unaware of human sin
It means God is a distant judge
questions.correctAnswer: It affirms God as the source of the psalmist's righteousness
questions.explanation: Calling God the 'God of my righteousness' acknowledges that true righteousness comes from God, not human merit (Psalms 4:1). This is consistent with biblical doctrine of justification by God's grace (Psalm 7:17, Isaiah 64:6, Romans 3:22, Philippians 3:9, 2 Corinthians 5:21).

questions.question: How does Psalms 4:3 contribute to the doctrine of election?
options: The LORD has set apart the godly for Himself
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD has set apart the godly for Himself
questions.explanation: The verse states that God sets apart the godly for Himself, reflecting the biblical theme of divine election and God's sovereign choice (Psalms 4:3). This aligns with scriptures on God's selection of His people (Deuteronomy 7:6, Romans 8:33, Ephesians 1:4, John 15:16, 2 Timothy 1:9).

questions.question: What theological principle is taught by the command in Psalms 4:4 to 'commune with your own heart upon your bed, and be still'?
options: The importance of self-examination and trust in God
questions.correctAnswer: The importance of self-examination and trust in God
questions.explanation: The instruction to commune with one's heart and be still encourages introspection and reliance on God, foundational for spiritual growth (Psalms 4:4). Biblical teachings consistently promote self-examination and peaceful trust (Lamentations 3:40, 1 Corinthians 11:28, Psalm 46:10, Philippians 4:6-7, James 1:5).

questions.question: What does the phrase 'Offer the sacrifices of righteousness' in Psalms 4:5 convey about true worship?
options: True worship requires righteousness and faith
questions.correctAnswer: True worship requires righteousness and faith
questions.explanation: The verse teaches that worship must be accompanied by righteousness and trust in God, emphasizing inward faith over mere ritual (Psalms 4:5). This is consistent with biblical calls for sincere worship (Isaiah 1:11-17, Micah 6:6-8, Hebrews 11:6, Romans 12:1, John 4:23-24).

questions.question: What eschatological hope can be inferred from the psalmist's confidence in safety in Psalms 4:8?
options: God’s protection assures ultimate peace beyond present trials
This life is all there is
questions.correctAnswer: God’s protection assures ultimate peace beyond present trials
questions.explanation: The psalmist's peace and safety reflect trust in God's eternal protection, foreshadowing eschatological security for the faithful (Psalms 4:8). Scripture promises believers ultimate rest and safety in God's presence (Revelation 21:4, Isaiah 26:3, John 14:27, Hebrews 4:9-11, Psalm 91).

questions.question: How does Psalms 4:6 respond to the question 'Who will show us any good?'?
options: It appeals to the LORD to lift His countenance upon them
It denies any good can come
questions.correctAnswer: It appeals to the LORD to lift His countenance upon them
questions.explanation: The psalmist responds by asking God to show favor, teaching that true good comes from God's blessing (Psalms 4:6). This matches biblical teaching that God's presence is the source of blessing (Psalm 67:1, James 1:17, Jeremiah 29:11, Psalm 23:6, Matthew 6:33).

questions.question: What aspect of God’s character is emphasized by the psalmist's experience in Psalms 4:1 during distress?
options: God’s mercy and deliverance in times of trouble
questions.correctAnswer: God’s mercy and deliverance in times of trouble
questions.explanation: David acknowledges God's mercy and enlargement during distress, highlighting God's compassion and saving power (Psalms 4:1). This is consistent with God's character as a refuge and helper (Psalm 34:18, Nahum 1:7, Lamentations 3:22-23, 2 Corinthians 1:3-4, Isaiah 41:10).
